channel.title: Teaching on Xiaoqi Tan @UAlberta
channel.description: Recent content in Teaching on Xiaoqi Tan @UAlberta

item.title: CMPUT 204 - Fall 2025
item.description:
CMPUT 204: Algorithms I (Fall 2025)

Instructor: Xiaoqi Tan ($\textsf{xiaoqi.tan@ualberta.ca}$)
Location & Time: C E1-60; MWF 11:00â€“11:50am
Office hour: Wednesday 2-3pm

Course Topics

  1. Foundations. Concepts; Model of computation; Loop invariants and inductions; Asymptotic growth of functions; Recurrence relations
  2. Data Structures. Heaps; Priority queue; Binary search tree; AVL tree; Hash table
  3. Algorithm Design Paradigms
    • Divide and conquer: Merge Sort; QuickSort and random quicksort; Large integer multiplication; Matrix multiplication; Advanced topics
    • Greedy algorithms: Fractional knapsack; Job scheduling; Activity selection; Advanced topics
    • Dynamic programming: Integral knapsack; Rod cutting; Longgest common subsequence; Matrix chain multiplication; Advanced topics
  4. Graphs. Graph representation; Graph traversals: BFS/DFS; Directed acyclic graphs and topological sort; Connectivity in directed graphs; Minimum spanning trees; Single-source shortest path; All-pairs shortest path

Course Schedule

Date Topics References
Week 1: Introduction; Insertion Sort CLRS: Ch1-Ch4
Jan 5 Course overview Lecture 1-slides
Lecture 1-video
Jan 7 RAM; Insertion Sort (getting started) Lecture 2-slides
Lecture 2-video
Week 2: Loop Invariants; Insertion Sort Analysis
Jan 10 Loop invariants: concepts Lecture 3-slides
Lecture 3-video
Jan 12 Loop invariants: more examples Lecture 4-slides
Lecture 4-video
Jan 14 Loop invariants: Insertion Sort analysis Lecture 5-slides
Lecture 5-video
Week 3: Asymptotic Growth of Functions
Jan 17 Big-O notation: Part 1 Lecture 6-slides
Lecture 6-video
Jan 19 Big-O notation: Part 2 Lecture 7-slides
Lecture 7-video
Jan 21 Big-O notation: Part 3 Lecture 8-slides
Lecture 8-video
Week 4: Divide-and-Conquer I
(Merge Sort and Recurrence Relations)
Jan 24 Merge Sort; Recurrence relations Lecture 9-slides
Lecture 9-video
Jan 26 Methods for solving recurrence: Subsitution; Recursion tree Lecture 10-slides
Lecture 10-video
Jan 28 Methods for solving recurrence: Master Theorem Lecture 11-slides
Lecture 11-video
Week 5: Heaps; Priority Queue; HeapSort
Jan 31 Heaps Lecture 12-slides
Lecture 12-video
Feb 2 Heaps; HeapSort Lecture 13-slides
Lecture 13-video
Feb 4 Priority queue Lecture 14-slides
Lecture 14-video
Week 6: QuickSort; SLB; BST; Hash Table
Feb 7 QuickSort Lecture 15-slides
Lecture 15-video
Feb 9 QuickSort analysis; Random QuickSort
Sorting lower bound		 Lecture 16-slides
Lecture 16-video
Feb 11 BST: binary search tree
Balanced BST: AVL tree
Hash tables		 Lecture 17-slides
Lecture 17-video
Week 7: Greedy Algorithms
Feb 14 Fractional knapsack Lecture 18-slides
Lecture 18-video
Feb 16 Job scheduling Lecture 19-slides
Lecture 19-video
Feb 18 Activity selection Lecture 20-slides
Lecture 20-video
Week 8: Reading Week
Week 9: Divide-and-Conquer II
Feb 28 Test 1 (Coverage: Week 1–Week 6)
Mar 2 Karatsuba’s algorithm Lecture 21-slides
Lecture 21-video
Mar 4 Strassen’s algorithm Lecture 22-slides
Lecture 22-video
Week 10: Dynamic Programming
Mar 7 Introduction
Getting started: Fibonacci		 Lecture 23-slides
Lecture 23-video
Mar 9 Integral knapsack
Rod cutting		 Lecture 24-slides
Lecture 24-video
Mar 11 Longest common subsequence
Matrix chain multiplication		 Lecture 25-slides
Lecture 25-video
Week 11: Graphs and BFS/DFS
Mar 14 Graphs: Introduction Lecture 26-slides
Lecture 26-video
Mar 16 BFS: Breadth-First Search Lecture 27-slides
Lecture 27-video
Mar 18 DFS: Depth-First Search Lecture 28-slides
Lecture 28-video
Week 12: DAGs; TopoSort; SCCs; MST
Mar 21 DAG: Directed Acyclic Graphs Lecture 29-slides
Lecture 29-video
Mar 23 TopoSort: Topological Sorting in DAGs
SCCs: Strongly connected components		 Lecture 30-slides
Lecture 30-video
Mar 25 MST: Minimum spanning tree
Kruskal’s algorithm: Introduction		 Lecture 31-slides
Lecture 31-video
Week 13: Minimum Spanning Tree (Cont'd)
Mar 28 Test 2 (Coverage: Week 7–Week 11)
Mar 30 Kruskal’s algorithm: Proof
Prim’s algorithm: Introduction		 Lecture 32-slides
Lecture 32-video
April 1 Prim’s algorithm: Proof Lecture 33-slides
Lecture 33-video
Week 14: Shortest Path
April 4 Dijkstra Lecture 34-slides
Lecture 34-video
April 6 Bellman-Ford Lecture 35-slides
Lecture 35-video
April 8 Floyd-Warshall
Course recap		 Lecture 36-slides
Lecture 36-video

Some Advices

  1. How to use the course material
    • Pre-lectures: Go through the lecture notes and slides before each lecture. Failure to do so will make it very hard to follow the lectures in class. This session is recommended for every student with at least 30 minutes.
    • Post-lectures: Review the lecture notes and slides after each lecture. This is recommended for every student, especially when you are confused about some topics discussed in class. at least 30 minutes.
  2. How to understand the course topics. Heaps; Priority queue; Binary search tree; AVL tree; Hash table
  3. Assignments: Merge Sort; QuickSort and random quicksort; Large integer multiplication; Matrix multiplication; Advanced topics; Fractional knapsack; Job scheduling; Activity selection; Advanced topics; Integral knapsack; Rod cutting; Longgest common subsequence; Matrix chain multiplication; Advanced topics
  4. Term Test 1 + Term Test 2. Graph representation; Graph traversals: BFS/DFS; Directed acyclic graphs and topological sort; Connectivity in directed graphs; Minimum spanning trees; Single-source shortest path; All-pairs shortest path
  5. Final Exam. The final exam will cover all the topics discussed in this course, with an emphasis on algorithm design and analysis. Compared to the two term tests, the final exam is relatively harder in the sense that a considerable amount of questions may look new to you.

item.title: CMPUT676 - Fall 2024
item.description:
CMPUT 676: Optimization and Decision-Making under Uncertainty

Fall 2024

Instructor: Xiaoqi Tan (xiaoqi.tan$\textsf{@}$ualberta.ca)
Location & Time: GSB 7-11, MW 12:00 PM â€“ 1:20 PM
Office hour: After class or by appointment\

Course Overview

Many real-world problems involve making decisions over time in the presence of various forms of uncertainty. These challenges arise in fields such as Internet advertising, energy sustainability, transportation, financial trading, healthcare, and a wide range of problems in artificial intelligence and machine learning. Although these specific decision problems may initially appear different in various application scenarios, the models and algorithms needed to address them are often similar.
